Message.Title: It's a Win Win no matter what happens
Message.Msg: Here are the likely scenarios: a. There is a competing bid at a higher price or b. No competing bids emerge Under scenario b. the prevailing wisdom is that the stock price will fall back to below $13.65 a share. However, let's analyze this scenario further. Yes, there may be an initial drop but what comes next. Dell, Silver Lake, et al will release the proxy next week trying to win support for their bid. We already know that if large shareholders think the price is too low they are not going to vote for it, neither will Icahn. So either Dell increases his bid price which is a good thing for shareholders, or the bid is rejected. If the bid is rejected, does the price fall back to $11? Not a chance. And if it did I would swoope in and buy it as would Icahn and other funds, why? Because there already was a higher bid at $13.65 and these players feel it is worth much more. At that point, there would be a challenge via Icahn to replace the Board, which would probably happen, and there would be a huge dividend payout, which is also a good thing for shareholders. Icahn isn't buying 100 million shares just a make a buck or two, he is in this to make upwards of $5 or more per share. I actually hope no alternative offer emerges, the stock drops where I'll buy more, then the vote is against the bid, then Icahn works his magic to force the company to return the cash to the owners. In any scenario, its a win win for the current shareholders and that is why I am buying on dips and still pounding the table and yelling BUY on this play.

Topic.Title: It's a Win Win no matter what happens

Message.Msg: Agreed...I dont fathom any situation where the stock goes below $13.65 In fact, like you said, there is only 1 way and that is up. If there is no deal, then Icahn will ensure a dividend ...I mean let's face it ..he doesn't give a _______ about DELL. He is in it to make money SouthEastern's average on their shares is $16.88 There is no way they are gonna vote for the current LBO. Unless there is another consortium willing to pay close to $17 - $18 I dont see why there is gonna be a buyout at all

Topic.Title: It's a Win Win no matter what happens

Message.Msg: Additionally, since the LBO was proposed and DELL has been stuck in a trading range, HPQ has rallied about 15%, so DELL should really be trading at $17 right now. They've got net cash after paying off debt (including their financing receivables, most of which is short term) of $6.23/share. If I had $14/share available, I'd buy the company, pay off the debt, monetize the $6/share of net cash and pay myself back a large dividend, then be sitting with a debt-free company for essentially $8/share. One that is projected to earn $1.57 aftertax this year (probably closer to $1.85 cashflow). It's a no brainer. Then wait a couple years and float an IPO for $20/share. Hello Carl? Are you listening?
